column1: We are now at a point where the doctors are giving us no hope

column1: This year the doctors informed us his brain is beginning to degenerate he has been placed on palliative care. My parents are flying out to NYU November 9th-14th to see if another opinion can provide us with any hope.

column3: he has developed severe OCD behaviors
column4: is in a constant state of nausea and discomfort. Through out his early years he was suffering from dozens of short though incoherent seizure episodes which have progressed into what seems non stop small seizures that are constantly debilitating him. He head which is rather scarred from repeated surgeries and though has undergone plastic surgery to try and restructure with mesh (for functional reasons) seems to be caving in and areas of the scar are not healing correctly and are constantly getting infected.

column1: The situation escalated to the point where I lost about 8 lbs in a week and a half (went from 150-142) and I finally went to see a GI in mid-October. They performed an ultrasound of my gallbladder (clean!) and also did some blood work
column2: which also came back clean.  The GI prescribed me 10mg dicyclomine to be taken 3 times a day
column3: as well as a week long course of ciprofloxacin.  I responded well to the dicyclomine at first -- my first two days on the pills I felt almost normal.  But it started to have some diminishing returns pretty quickly
column4: so I spoke with my GI and decided to take it four times a day.  Once again
column5: I'm experiencing some diminishing returns and I am now taking dicyclomine five times a day.  He also recommended I take 20g omeprazole twice a day
column6: which I have been doing for several weeks.  I saw him for a followup on Weds and explained I was still experiencing nausea and difficulty eating
column7: so he's now added a probiotic (Align
column8: taken I believe once daily?  I haven't started yet
column9: I ordered the pills online and they should be arriving today) and he suggested taking a Tums before bedtime (which I have done for the last few days
column10: using ""ultra strength"" Tums.)

column1: Like I said
column2: the medication seemed to work at first.  I went from 142 to 144-46

column4: although a bit better than I did this morning.  The nausea is bad enough right now that I don't feel like I could function comfortably outside of my apartment.  I'm also starting to lose weight again (which yay
column5: I guess

column7: not because I can't eat food.)

column2: and was not nearly as serious as the nausea I experience now.  I just stuck to a diet of simple chicken broth and saltines until my stomach settled
column3: which it eventually did.  I didn't see a doctor for that.  I had also been losing weight intentionally prior to my stomach issues
column4: approximately 25 lbs before these shenanigans began. Back in June I experienced SEVERE
column5: sharp abdominal pain that lasted for about 4-5 days.  I saw the GI back then as well and he said it was likely a gallbladder attack from the weight loss and he gave me a prescription
column6: but by that point I was actually getting better on my own and didn't end up taking the medication.  Eventually the pain went away completely and I was totally fine pretty much until October when this whole mess started.

column3: soft BMs

column6: I suspect because I'm having so much trouble eating.  But who knows?  Urine seems to be pretty normal

column1: The nausea is basically constant but I've only thrown up once this whole time back in October
column2: and what I threw up was literally just a pill and water.  (There was nothing else in my system.)  I feel like if I pushed myself to eat more it would probably end up making me vomit
column3: but I haven't really wanted to try that yet.  Also
column4: the nausea seems to come in waves: it's always present
column5: but sometimes it just gets SO MUCH WORSE before ebbing back to a lower level.  Aside from the nausea I get occasional stomach discomfort (not pain

column13: so I'm assuming it was within normal range.  She said the difficulty getting a reading on my blood pressure was probably due to dehydration.  It's pretty difficult for me to swallow liquids without nausea at this point
column14: so it makes sense.  I'm gonna try sipping on some Gatorade today to see if it'll help me be a little less dehydrated.

column1: Full disclosure: before my stomach started misbehaving I vaporized marijuana recreationally
column2: anywhere from .1g to .5g a day.  I used to partake rarely back when I was in California
column3: primarily by using edibles.  I stopped for 6 months after moving from California to a fully illegal state and only resumed usage back in early August.  All told I've probably enjoyed weed for a total of about a little over a year
column4: but only since August did I become a daily user. Vaporizing the larger amounts (like .5g/day) is also a fairly recent development that I started in RESPONSE to my nausea
column5: I was definitely using smaller amounts when this all started.  I'm mentioning this because I have heard of Cannabinoid Hyperemesis Syndrome
column6: and while I'm fairly certain I don't have CHS I figure it's worth throwing out there as an option.  I will say that I just took a hot shower that seemed to relieve my symptoms temporarily
column7: but again I almost never vomit (which I understand is a hallmark symptom of CHS and CVS) so it just doesn't seem very likely.  I'm abstaining from marijuana for the next few days just to be sure
column8: but I have to say that it is difficult because marijuana is about the only thing that seems to reliably alleviate my symptoms.  It's also the only way I can manage to eat more than two bites of something without wanting to puke it all back up.  On that note
column9: if cannabis isn't the cause of my symptoms is it still safe for me to use it to treat my nausea?  (Yes
column10: I understand ""safe"" is kind of a relative term when you're getting it from a dealer rather than a medical dispensary
column11: but I do trust my guy and nobody else appears to be getting sick from his product.)  I understand that marijuana can slow gut motility
column12: and if my issue is related to gastroparesis then I definitely don't want to exacerbate the problem
column13: you know?  I have not yet disclosed my marijuana usage to my GI (he hasn't asked yet and he's a friend of the family
column14: so I can't help but feel a little paranoid that he'd tell my folks) but if it is relevant I will obviously do so.

column1: Alrighty so yesterday I was walking to the bathroom all the way from the garage (Detached building in the backyard).

About 1/4 way up the steps to the second floor I get a weird feeling in my gut and a sudden heavyness. I brushed off the heaviness as the weed I was smoking beforehand and the stomach sensation as just really needing to go to the washroom. I had just been in 10 minutes prior so I figured my stomach was just upset. I make it up the short steps and it gets worse. My mind connects the gut sensation to a few experiences where I pass out or feel like I am coming close. I should've just sat down right away but that requires good fore-thought. I get a few steps into the bathroom and then darkness...
Next thing I know I am on the floor with my heart beating out of my chest
column2: cold
column3: covered in sweat
column4: and towels. I cannot bring myself to open my eyes because of an overwhealming sound of blood circulating. All I can focus on for the next 30 seconds (but felt like an eternity) is the sound and how human are not supposed to hear it normally. I open my eyes
column5: slowy sit up
column6: and try to gather together what happened. I stand with the same stability of a newborn calf and stumble to the kitchen to let my grandma know I was all right and what happened. column1: I come back

column1: Background: Mother is 52

column1: She is having attacks lately where she loses motor control (can't stand up)
column2: slurs her speech and cries hysterically in high stress situations.  She is mentally aware and has full recollections of all details during the attacks
column3: and is even aware enough during the attacks to ask for things unrelated to her situation (like the the cat out
column4: get me my blood pressure tester
column5: etc).  Her blood pressure readings during these attacks are elevated but not health crisis levels (150/95 is average I'd say)
column6: afterwards when the attack ends in typically 15 to 30 minutes it drops to normal levels around 130-135/90 and she returns to normal completely with no issues with motor function.

column1: Her doctor thought these attacks were stress related and had her do several MRI's and CT scans to rule out stroke symptoms due to the loss of motor control.  These scans were also reviewed by a neurologist who signed off that he saw no stroke signs.  He put her on lexipro
column2: and she has been taking it for about 30 days.  Last week without telling me she discontinued because she said she didn't like how it 'felt'.  At work on tuesday she complained of a splitting headache
column3: and her leg went numb.  She now needs a walker to walk on her own because the leg that went numb gives out on her sometimes.  More CT scans and MRIs showed no signs of stroke symptoms.

column1: She now is complaining about a sort of travelling numbness in her face
column2: it started around her mouth after she had the headache
column3: and has moved up to her eyebrows and hairline.  Her left eyebrow has a very slight droop when resting
column4: but she is able to open both eyes fully and also make a ""surprised"" face completely evenly.

column1: Honestly

column3: or something else entirely? "	"Doctor Question: And her labs were normal? Including B vitamins?

column1: Patient Response: Yes I would work (still do) and would faint quite a bit and would get injured sometimes so it was becoming a real issue. It turns out I have autonomic failure on all branches
column2: dystaunomia (usually its a certain type but my doctor can’t find any) and mast cell activation syndrome (found by biopsy) and neuropathy.(found by biopsy)This was all distinguished just by the  tilt table test with biopsy! column3: I had done that before and a cardiologist looked at it very quickly (since I’m only 26 and everyone writes me off as being healthy/having anxiety) so finally I seen the chief neurologist at the best Boston hospital and he took me serious and did a great tilt table test WITH a biopsy and I feel so relieved that I’m not crazy! column12: I mean they are always exposed to illnesses and don’t wash their hands before touching things. I don’t hate kids! It’s worth noting  I hadn’t yet gotten my flu shot
column13: but I wasn’t all that concerned
column15: I keep my hands away from my face when they aren’t clean
column16: always wash my hands before I eat anything
column17: and even open doors with my shirt covering my hand.

column1: I left after a few hours. The following evening
column2: my throat was ever so slightly sore. That’s a big red flag for me
column3: but I went to bed and hoped it wasn’t going to be brutal. I woke up the next morning with a hellish pain in my throat. It hurt to swallow. It hurt to drink. It hurt. Period. My ears were popping and aching as well. I went to assess the damage and noticed white blotches behind my uvula
column4: which seemed off. After a few hours and two Ibuprofen
column5: the throat pain was pretty minimal
column6: though my ears were still popping. Later that evening
column7: I developed a cough
column8: which only got worse as the night went on. All this combined with me coughing up phlegm
column9: I decided to go to a walk in clinic the following day if I remained this way. I woke up in the morning
column10: and I actually felt quite a bit better. I was still coughing up phlegm
column11: and my cough was now a constant symptom
column12: but my throat felt pretty okay. Nonetheless
column13: I went to the clinic that evening. I explained my symptoms
column15: which they obliged. The test came back negative
column16: and the doctor said apart from my ears having some fluid in them
column17: it seemed like a normal viral infection. Since I didn’t have a fever
column19: I also got my flu shot while I was there. Truthfully
column20: I still wasn’t entirely convinced by the strep test
column21: as I recall having strep when I was younger that only showed itself in a bacteria culture a few days after I went to the doctor and had the quick strep test come back negative. I figured
column23: they might not have been prepared to do a bacteria culture
column24: so I didn’t say anything. I was told to come back if my ears got worse
column25: and that was that. The next day (yesterday)
column26: I woke up and I was worse. My throat hurt again
column29: and my cough was even more aggressive. I took Ibuprofen and it didn’t help. I ended up canceling my plans
column30: went back to sleep for a few hours
column32: I felt considerably better. Not good
column33: but better. My symptoms were just less aggressive. I wasn’t completely alarmed by this because I figured maybe it would just get worse before it gets better. Went about my day
column35: we’re at today. I wake up
column36: and my throat felt even worse. My nose was stuffed
column39: and I had a splitting headache. I took some Ibuprofen and went back to sleep. That was a few hours ago
column41: I’ve still got that splitting headache. My ears still ache. My throat doesn’t hurt as bad
column42: but it still hurts. I know I’m definitively worse than I was yesterday. I won’t be able to get to the clinic today
column43: but this is still alarming for me considering my past experiences getting sick. What should I do? I can’t get to the clinic
column44: meaning my only option would be to call 911. I think that’s probably a bit too drastic
column45: but that’s the only way I’d be able to seek medical help until tomorrow. I’m sure I can ride this out until tomorrow
column46: but my throat looks inflamed and those white blotches are still there. Is it safe to wait until tomorrow
column47: or should I get medical help ASAP before this potentially turns into something serious?

column2: no matter what I eat

column1: Nausea every time I eat

column1: This first started in 2017 when I returned to the US after living in South America for about a year. I hated eating because it made me nauseous. But not like “I’m going to throw up” nauseous
column2: but just supremely uncomfortable. And it’s a very distinct sensation I’ve only experienced with whatever this is that’s happening to me. It’s like nausea but... in my throat? Like right behind my clavicle region. I honestly thought I contracted a worm or something my last few days in South America
column3: but being a genius and never went to a physician about it.

column1: Well after about 6 months of that I started eating vegetarian and somehow that fixed it for me. I know longer had that sensation (And never found any evidence of worms). Fast forward to the last 2 months and it has started back up (admittedly I stopped eating vegetarian for about a year)
column2: but now even when I try to eat vegetarian habitually I still feel the horribly uncomfortable sensation. It’s almost advanced
column3: to the point that drinking water aggravates it. But other times
column4: I’ll be really nauseous and when I finally force myself to eat
column5: it goes away. Sometimes I eat and nothing is wrong.

column1: I think I will start a log of what I eat and how I feel. Maybe that would help if it’s something in my diet.
My sister once described being nauseous but “in her throat” which is the only time I’ve heard anyone else be able to relate to the feeling
column2: but neither of my parents. However
column3: she never related anything as irritating as what I am experiencing. My other sister has issues with her gall bladder
column4: but the nausea this causes her when she eats the wrong foods often ends up with her vomiting. I have never done so with my... whatever it is.

column1: True	t_fb0chpm-0	"Recurring fevers - exact same symptoms every few weeks or months
column2: and no one ever gets sick from me. After having bloodwork done while sick
column3: it’s come to light that my CRP level spiked to 49.9
column4: and then back down to 0.77 when I’m healthy.

column1: Hello everyone
I’m sorry for the long title
column2: I just wanted to get as much info in as I could. My name is Aaron
column3: I’m a 24 year old male
column4: and I live in Canada.

column1: For as far back as I can remember
column2: I’ve been sick what I felt has been way more often than any of my friends. I didn’t realize at the time
column3: but every single time I’ve been sick (aside from maybe the odd cold?) has been the EXACT SAME symptoms - this includes a fever of typically 38.9
column4: a very sore throat
column5: congestion
column6: and a cough.

column1: Initially
column2: my mom and I believed I was constantly getting strep throat over and over again
column3: so I would be treated as if it was and it would eventually go away. Like I said I don’t have a ton of memory on everything back then because I didn’t think anything of it at the time.

column1: Then
column2: we come to the last few years. I started to notice the pattern about 2 years ago when I first met my girlfriend. I got extremely sick like I usually do on New Years
column3: and it lasted a couple of weeks like it usually does - but about 3 weeks later
column4: I got sick again. Same symptoms. Fast forward to February
column5: about a month later
column6: I’m sick again with the same symptoms. March
column7: about a month later again - same symptoms. April
column8: about 3 weeks later
column9: I’m sick again with the same symptoms as always.

column1: It was around this time that my mom and I noticed that nobody ever gets sick from me. I’m never
column2: ever contagious - it almost seems like my body’s reaction to something rather than an illness.

column1: This pattern continued for about a year
column2: up until last New Years when I got sick again. I finally had enough and I decided to go to a walk in and explain my situation. I met a doctor who finally was willing to look into what this could be
column3: rather than just marking it off as a cold or strep throat. He gave me some forms to get bloodwork done once when I was healthy
column4: and again when I was sick.

column1: I waited until I was sick to get my bloodwork done
column2: but
column3: to my surprise
column4: I didn’t get sick this year until about 9 months later. Come October
column5: sure enough i was sick with the same symptoms as always. I got my bloodwork done while I was sick
column6: and to my surprise all of my results came back normal EXCEPT - I had a CRP level of 49.9. I’m lucky enough to be dating and living with my girlfriend who is a Registered Nurse
column7: and she explained to me that a high CRP level indicates some sort of swelling in the body
column8: and could really be chalked up to anything.

column1: So
column2: when I was healthy
column3: I went back to get my blood work done. After getting it done
column4: I went back into the same walk in clinic and spoke with the doctor who was willing to look into what it could be.

column1: He explained to me that my CRP had spiked to 49.9 while I was sick
column2: and had fallen back down to 0.77 while I was healthy. He said that usually with something like a cold or the flu
column3: you could expect to see CRP levels of 13 or so due to a cough or a sore throat causing some swelling - but he said because it spiked to high
column4: he thinks we could be on the right track and it could be something else.

column1: One thing we’re looking into is something called Periodic Fever Syndrome. This is usually (rarely) found in children
column2: and typically doesn’t last until adulthood. Some adults however can even more rarely be diagnosed with this.

column1: With all of that being said
column2: that brings me to today. I was sick about a month ago
column3: and surprise surprise I’m sick again. Last night my fever started out at around 37.9 when I noticed it
column4: and I woke up about an hour and a half ago with a fever of 38.8 (Celsius of course).

column1: I’m going to wait a few days
column2: and when whatever this is is at its peak
column3: I’m going to get bloodwork again to see if my CRP spikes back up again. If it does
column4: the doctor said he will most likely try to treat it as if it’s Periodic Fever Syndrome:

column1: The reason I’m writing in is to see if anyone else has something like this
column2: or if any doctors have any opinions or insight they would be willing to share.

column1: I’m so tired of being constantly sick. It’s effected many jobs as I have to call in sick
column2: it effects my day to day and general happiness
column3: and I just want it to stop.

column1: Thank you for reading all of this."	"Doctor Question: Do you smoke?
Patient Response: I don’t smoke
Doctor Question: Do you live somewhere with mold or at least very damp?
Patient Response: As far as I know there’s no mold or dampness here
Doctor Question: Do you have a healthy diet?
Patient Response: My diet is okay but I could definitely cut out the junk food
Doctor Question: How often are you exercising?
Patient Response: None
Doctor Question: How is your sleep schedule?
Patient Response: My sleep schedule is definitely not the best
column2: it sometimes takes me until 2 am to fall asleep

column1: Doctor Question: Have you ever gotten a throat swab?
Patient Response: As for throat swabs
column2: I’ve definitely had my fair share. As far as I can remember they all come back negative for strep
column3: and I’ve never heard the doctors suggest anything else other than maybe a cold"	Which condition is the doctor most likely considering based on the patient’s pattern of recurrent fevers
column4: elevated CRP levels
column5: and negative strep tests?	Chronic strep infection	Allergic rhinitis	Infectious mononucleosis	Periodic Fever Syndrome	D

He prescribed be antibiotics for 7 days. They seemed to work but then near the end of the prescription the pain began coming back. After a long waiting period to have another appointment I got in. At this point he prescribed me another round of antibiotics that stay in my system longer after taking the last dose (5 doses
column2: 9 days in my system). They seemed once again to help but the sore throat has slowly coming back. After my third visit (today) I was hoping for a referral or tests. Something to look further into the cause. But instead he prescribed YET ANOTHER 10 Days of antibiotics saying he’ll refer me if after the appointment 10 days from now it appears to still be inflamed. Should I be concerned about taking this many antibiotics? That’s 3 rounds in less than 2 months. This most recent prescription is 30 capsules of amoxicillin.

column1: My boyfriend began having issues with bad breath in college (around 2015). We started dating in 2017. I think he’s a great guy and would hate to end the relationship over this
column2: but it’s been an issue that has really affected our intimacy. We’re moving in together soon
column3: so both of us would love to have this issue solved ASAP...

column1: About the problem: He says it began around the same time as he transitioned his diet from that of an offensive lineman on the football team (basically eating whatever/whenever he wanted) to a healthier
column2: more restricted diet. He went to the doctor for it soon after the issue began and was told that it was most likely related to the dietary change
column3: which may have changed the composition of his stomach acid.

column1: Since then
column2: he’s been using prescription-strength toothpaste designed to improve breath. But almost five years later the problem still hasn’t improved. He brushes his teeth 2-3 times a day with the “BreathRx” toothpaste. He doesn’t floss regularly
column3: but neither do many people I know
column4: and their breath is nowhere near as bad.

column3: especially during a virus (I think). Sometimes high blood pressure. Also for years had heart palpitations or skipped heart beats once a week but the last month it happens multiple times a week or day (probably stress related). They referred me to a cardiologist which I go to tomorrow.

True	t_gh4f455-0	"Infant girl three weeks of age has had two choking incidents
column2: one of which made her spend her first Christmas in hospital.

column1: Bit of a heavy one here
column2: but I NEED advice.

column1: (Also sorry for the spelling and grammar I’m not the smartest when it comes to that stuff.)

So on the first of December I gave birth to the most beautiful baby girl. She weighed 6lbs 2oz and was the picture of health and happiness. Everything was going perfect until the end of her first week of life
column2: I looked down at her and she was red and wide eyed and flopping her head around in distress... I realised she was choking
column3: I scooped her up and when she was up right and had a few sharp blast to the back vomit started to come out of her nose and mouth
column4: she started crying when the vomit started gushing so I knew that she could breath again. Now this whole incident only last in total 5-8 seconds
column5: but it really shook me. After she was better I was so relieved but I was immediately worried it was going to happen again so I asked my partner/ mum/ partners mum and dad/ friends who are parents / doctors/ midwife/ health visitor and they all pretty much told me it would be fine and she would have cleared it herself if had of been asleep or not watching her because ‘that’s how babies are designed ‘
column6: but they didn’t see it
column7: they didn’t see the fear in her eyes and how she was acting. It was honestly so frustrating to not be listened to or taken seriously about this of all things.

column1: Nevertheless even though it went against what I believed
column2: I listened to them and settled myself and made myself chalk it down as a freak accident and told myself that she would have been fine if I hadn’t of helped her.

column1: Fast forward to Christmas Eve and me and my partner where just about to go to sleep
column2: I was actually already drifting off and he screams she not breathing
column3: it was happening again but this time it was way worse
column4: she was wide eyed again and flopping about in distress but this time when she was sat up and patted on the back nothing was happening and she started moving a lot less and her eyes closed
column5: she was starting to turn purple
column6: basically she was about to choke to death. Thankfully after the last time I watched some infant first aid videos
column7: so i asked my partner to hold her head down and I opened her mouth and stuck my finger in and hooked the thick liquid stuff that was in the throat and started pulling it out
column8: she let of one little tiny cry so I knew it was working to some degree so I ran into the kitchen and got the mucus sucker and with one hand used it on her nose and the other hand to hook the stuff out of her throat again . Finally she cried a few times and began to breath and even though she was foaming at the mouth and very weak I could tell she was atleast breathing again
column9: this whole incident last 40 seconds. Once we got her breathing again we called an ambulance
column10: they took her in to hospital and observed her for a while and advised on some changes in food (both the amount and type) and said she should be fine.

column1: Now here’s my problem
column2: everyone said she was fine the first time too
column3: but clearly it happened again and to a much worse degree!

column1: Now me and my partner are taking full shifts so she is always with someone who is awake and fully alert
column2: which is fine but I can’t relax
column3: I spent eight hours solidly just staring at her watching her breathing and panicking every time she moved or made a noise. I genuinely don’t know how I am meant to cope with this fear that she is going to die any second
column4: I can’t enjoy any time with her because I’m so stressed even though I want to be able to enjoy being with her I just can’t over the past few days. I don’t know what to do
column5: does anybody have advice or has anyone been through similar experience?"	"Doctor Question: What is she being fed?

column1: Patient Response: None"	Based on the mother's concerns about the repeated choking episodes and her intense anxiety
column2: what is the most appropriate next step?	Routinely suction the infant's nose and mouth before and after each feeding.	Accept that some choking episodes are normal and rely only on home observation.	Arrange follow-up with a healthcare provider to evaluate feeding adjustments for possible reflux and address the mother’s anxiety.	Focus on managing the mother's stress with relaxation techniques only and make no further changes to the baby’s feeding plan.	C

column1: Bit of a heavy one here
column2: but I NEED advice.

column1: (Also sorry for the spelling and grammar I’m not the smartest when it comes to that stuff.)

So on the first of December I gave birth to the most beautiful baby girl. She weighed 6lbs 2oz and was the picture of health and happiness. Everything was going perfect until the end of her first week of life
column2: I looked down at her and she was red and wide eyed and flopping her head around in distress... I realised she was choking
column3: I scooped her up and when she was up right and had a few sharp blast to the back vomit started to come out of her nose and mouth
column4: she started crying when the vomit started gushing so I knew that she could breath again. Now this whole incident only last in total 5-8 seconds
column5: but it really shook me. After she was better I was so relieved but I was immediately worried it was going to happen again so I asked my partner/ mum/ partners mum and dad/ friends who are parents / doctors/ midwife/ health visitor and they all pretty much told me it would be fine and she would have cleared it herself if had of been asleep or not watching her because ‘that’s how babies are designed ‘
column6: but they didn’t see it
column7: they didn’t see the fear in her eyes and how she was acting. It was honestly so frustrating to not be listened to or taken seriously about this of all things.

column1: Nevertheless even though it went against what I believed
column2: I listened to them and settled myself and made myself chalk it down as a freak accident and told myself that she would have been fine if I hadn’t of helped her.

column1: Fast forward to Christmas Eve and me and my partner where just about to go to sleep
column2: I was actually already drifting off and he screams she not breathing
column3: it was happening again but this time it was way worse
column4: she was wide eyed again and flopping about in distress but this time when she was sat up and patted on the back nothing was happening and she started moving a lot less and her eyes closed
column5: she was starting to turn purple
column6: basically she was about to choke to death. Thankfully after the last time I watched some infant first aid videos
column7: so i asked my partner to hold her head down and I opened her mouth and stuck my finger in and hooked the thick liquid stuff that was in the throat and started pulling it out
column8: she let of one little tiny cry so I knew it was working to some degree so I ran into the kitchen and got the mucus sucker and with one hand used it on her nose and the other hand to hook the stuff out of her throat again . Finally she cried a few times and began to breath and even though she was foaming at the mouth and very weak I could tell she was atleast breathing again
column9: this whole incident last 40 seconds. Once we got her breathing again we called an ambulance
column10: they took her in to hospital and observed her for a while and advised on some changes in food (both the amount and type) and said she should be fine.

column1: Now here’s my problem
column2: everyone said she was fine the first time too
column3: but clearly it happened again and to a much worse degree!

column1: Now me and my partner are taking full shifts so she is always with someone who is awake and fully alert
column2: which is fine but I can’t relax
column3: I spent eight hours solidly just staring at her watching her breathing and panicking every time she moved or made a noise. I genuinely don’t know how I am meant to cope with this fear that she is going to die any second
column4: I can’t enjoy any time with her because I’m so stressed even though I want to be able to enjoy being with her I just can’t over the past few days. I don’t know what to do
column5: does anybody have advice or has anyone been through similar experience?"	"Doctor Question: could she have been having a seizure?

column1: Patient Response: They checked that when she got to the hospital but said it wasn’t a seizure
column2: they said it was left over mucus mixed with milk and due the the force in which it came up it bubbled and made it appear foamy."	Which statement best explains the cause of the infant’s choking episodes
column3: according to the hospital evaluation?	They indicated an underlying congenital heart condition.	They were caused by leftover mucus mixed with milk.	They were triggered by an allergic reaction to formula.	They resulted from an undiagnosed seizure disorder.	B

column1: True	t_ghjzw0z-0	"Frustrated nurse with weird fecal vomiting case
I'm a nurse in a group home for adults with severe multiple handicaps (Netherlands) and we are often not taken serious by doctors. For the past few days one of my residents (male
column2: 66) has been very upset
column3: hitting everyone who comes close to him (he only ever does this when he is very uncomfortable but it has been exteme and all our interventions do nothing
column4: ie; painkillers
column5: change of position
column6: less stimuli or more). He has **bloating in his stomach**
column7: it sounds hollow when you knock on his upper right part of his abdomen. Now keep in mind
column8: this man's body is pretty malformed
column9: we have no idea what his skeleton looks like or how his organs are situated. He has had sennosides
column10: a lot of macrogol and received enemas every other day
column11: his defecation pattern was normal (his **defecation is always water thin** because of laxatives and tube feedings). His **temperature wasn't high**  **(37

column1: Tonight he was **extremely upset
column2: feces came out of his J-tube** (he's had a J-tube for years and his intestine barely do anything anymore) and **out of his mouth.** We were sure he had an **ileus**. He was sent to the ER and was sent right back; CTscan didn't show any obstipation
column3: his urine levels were normal and his lungs looked normal as well. They just sent him home... The doctor says he thinks it's a stomach virus.

column1: Now I'm pretty young
column2: not very experienced
column3: but what kind of stomach virus could ever have anyone fecal vomit? I absolutely do not believe this.

column1: Any help? Has anyone seen something as strange as this before?
Edit: made improtant things bold + minor spelling corrections
Edit 31/12/2020: This morning my colleagues called our doctor again for any help
column2: since the hospital didn't provide us with anything else. The man had the audacity to prescribe **2x 500mg paractamol** and told us to **stop giving the resident Diclofenac because it would hurt his stomach more**... I cannot explain how angry I was. On top of that
column3: he told us to only call him if the resident got a fever.

column1: So my shift started
column2: I discussed the situation with a fellow colleague who was equally as angry as I was (the resident was still extremely upset
column3: hitting everything around him
column4: quick surface breathing
column5: we could easily see he was in pain. Family had arrived at that point and said the same. Once family says there;s something bad going on
column6: it's in our best interest to absolutely believe them). We called the doctor again
column7: after a few hours an assistant called back telling us the doctor prescribed **oxycodon** (5mg... but it's something to start with). He also allowed us to **decrease the tube feedings**; still the same speed
column8: just 50% water 50% peptisorb.

column1: Later in the afternoon and evening he slept
column2: slept and slept. He was calm
column3: I guess. The whole day after him being admitted to hospital
column4: there weren't any feces around his mouth or in his tube. Colleagues have pointed out that they would've recognized the smell of fecal vomiting
column5: and because his feces are so thin
column6: it could've been something else. But then again
column7: the man takes in nothing but white/yellow peptisorb. The colour of the liquid could potentionally point to **nexium** (? he does take this but has never had this color show up) or **old blood**
column8: which is still a massive problem. We weren't able to send him back to the ER since there was nothing accute going on anymore. The doctor didn't want to send him in again because he cannot say what's wrong...

column1: **Extra information that I had missed:** He wasn't being tube fed the first few hours in hospital and seemed to calm down because of that
column2: hence the change in his feeding pattern
column3: yet he was still angry.

column1: In his medical history this has happened before
column2: nothing was ever done but it always cleared up by itself after different tube feeding or antibiotics.

column1: He also has a **hernia diagfragmatica**

column3: hitting everyone who comes close to him (he only ever does this when he is very uncomfortable but it has been exteme and all our interventions do nothing

column8: just 50% water 50% peptisorb.

column1: Later in the afternoon and evening he slept

column3: I guess. The whole day after him being admitted to hospital

column8: which is still a massive problem. We weren't able to send him back to the ER since there was nothing accute going on anymore. The doctor didn't want to send him in again because he cannot say what's wrong...

column3: yet he was still angry.

Update 2 (I don't think anyone is still checking this but just in case) - Tumor marker test was negative but they did find a precancerous polyp from the colonoscopy."	"Doctor Question: Any symptoms of or evidence for autoimmune disease?
Patient Response: Blood in stool. They wanted to double check there was no active bleed before putting me on warfarin. I’m not sure what autoimmune diseases to ask about….any ideas?
Doctor Question: Also wondering why GI is on board?
Patient Response: Blood in stool. They wanted to double check there was no active bleed before putting me on warfarin.
Doctor Question: What is your CRP and your ESR? Not your CRP-hs but actual CRP?
Patient Response: None"	Based on the patient’s negative genetic testing
column2: negative APS
column3: and recurrent blood clots despite anticoagulation
column4: which condition still warrants further investigation alongside his GI symptoms (blood in stool) and intermittent anemia?	Factor V Leiden deficiency	Lynch syndrome	Antiphospholipid syndrome	Inflammatory bowel disease	D

column1: True	t_ho26o8n-1	"In Hospital Again...Need Real Life Dr. House

column2: white
column3: non smoker casual drinker.  I am currently in a hospital bed on a Heparin Drip.

column1: I have Vascular
column2: Hematology
column3: oncology
column4: and even Gastro all stumped.  Basically
column5: I am under attack by blood clots but no one has a clue why.   A year of this.

column1: Long story short - calf DVT 10/20.  Found May Thurner
column2: stent placed
column3: clot resolved
column4: moved on with life.   Taken off thinners.

column1: July - spinal surgery.  3 weeks later
column2: blood clots EVERYWHERE
column3: spent a week in hospital had thrombectomy.  Simple answer - surgery caused clots (even though ive had many surgeries before with no clots).  Put on Xarelto.

column1: November - found more clots even on Xarelto.  Do tPA lysis catheter puts me in hospital another week.  Clears clogged stents
column2: put on Lovenox.

column1: 2 weeks later - more clots.  Just had another thrombectomy.
I have tested negative for everything.  Negative for all genetic factors
column2: negative for rare clotting disorders.  And yet
column3: here I am.

column1: CT Scan of chest and pelvis no tumors.  Lymph nodes swollen but ""subcentimeter"" in the area where all the clotting keeps happening.
Everyone is stumped.  They won't let me out of the hospital. I feel fine except for my leg which has been through alot.
Only info to go off of - I have been anemic off and on
column2: Monocyte % slighly high
column3: folate very low
column4: absolute immature gran count high.

column1: True	t_hpttplp-0	"My significant other's health has sharply deteriorated and after months we have no idea what it is.
Hello. My (24F) boyfriend
column2: Paul (29M)
column3: and I are fairly active. We go on road trips every year with our main stops being prime hiking spots. Paul is 5'7'' and 230 pounds. Due to his southeast asian/pacific genetics
column4: his entire family is on the heavier side
column5: but Paul is just as active as I am and eats well.

column1: Recently
column2: we have gone long distance. Paul returned to live with his parents due to the pandemic while I stayed where I was. I visited him in June 2021. At this point
column3: Paul had few symptoms
column4: but some new minor health issues. We went hiking around Lake Tahoe and Paul was a little more out of breath than usual. He hasn't needed to use his inhaler since he was a kid
column5: and he had to use it on this trip. We attributed this to recent wildfires in the area and poor air quality.

column1: However
column2: Paul's health continued to sharply deteriorate. We went to Edinburgh
column3: Scotland
column4: in July. While hiking Arthur's Seat
column5: Paul had to use his inhaler so many times he emptied it out. He could not get it refilled as we were out of the country. Until the end of the trip
column6: Paul's breathing became more and more labored and he developed a persistent cough.

column1: I did not visit Paul August-November 2021. We spoke on the phone and Skyped regularly. During this time
column2: Paul would sometimes leave the call or mute for a few minutes. He'd come back and apologize
column3: saying he'd had to cough pretty violently and didn't want me to hear. I was concerned. I overheard one wracking
column4: moaning coughing session and knew it was not just asthma or an irritated throat. By October 2021
column5: the air quality in his area had greatly improved.

column1: I persuaded Paul to visit his general practitioner. His GP dismissed all of his concerns and cited Paul's being fat and asthmatic as the source of his issues
column2: and that the issues would disappear with rest and exercise. I had to fight doctors for years to get them to take my chronic pelvic pain seriously
column3: and was finally diagnosed with an ovarian cyst that was 8mm long and about to burst
column4: so I have experience with self advocacy in the medical space. I helped Paul see new doctors.

column1: In mid-October 2021
column2: Paul developed abdominal edema. Paul's feet
column3: legs
column4: and lower stomach were swelling up like crazy. He gained 40 pounds. He could barely move at all
column5: even to go to the bathroom. He couldn't sleep lying down without suffocating
column6: which only worsened his exhaustion. He went to the doctor again and was prescribed diuretics. The diuretics helped with the swelling and extra weight and within 2 weeks he was back to his regular weight
column7: but the coughing and weakness persisted.

column1: About a month after regularly taking diuretics (November)
column2: Paul started feeling intense nausea on a weekly basis. This nausea would prompt coughing fits. Paul couldn't eat or focus while nauseated. Our calls became more and more infrequent as Paul's nausea and headaches grew. He told me sometimes the nausea would get so bad that he would vomit. There were no patterns to the vomiting--it didn't happen at a certain time of day or after meals. Sometimes it was foamy. He got a CT scan to look at his gall bladder and all results were within normal ranges. Blood tests
column3: including labs for liver function
column4: all came back normal. His doctor referred him to a gastroenterologist for more testing
column5: but due to increases in COVID-19 cases
column6: they haven't even processed his file
